title: Are these the world’s best kept secrets?
text:
Havasu Falls are often overshadowed by the Grand Canyon. Source: Supplied 
INSPIRED to take a different travel path? Somewhere away from the crowds and relatively untouched? 
The Crooked Compass has found some of the world’s best undiscovered treasures for those moments when you’re looking for something not usually found on the tourist maps. 
Eben Ice Caves, Michigan, USA 
The Rock River Canyon Ice Cave — better known as the Eben Ice Caves — have remained a mystery to many largely because of their hidden location. 
Part of the 1600 hectare Rock River Wilderness area of the Hiawatha National Forest, the Eben Ice Caves come to life in winter when melting snow runs over the edge of a small cliff and freezes, forming “ice caves.” 
Tip: Wear boots with nice, grippy soles at the very minimum, and if possible, wear some sort of ice cleats on the bottoms of your shoes. Be awed by the hidden ice caves. Source: Supplied 
Laguna Salada de Torrevieja, Costa Blanca, Spain 
The Laguna Salada de Torrevieja is a natural phenomenon, where the water appears to be pink in colour due to a unique type of algae found in the water. 
Despite being saltier than sea water, there is no shortage of bird life here with over 2000 pairs of flamingoes often found during breeding season and 3000 pairs of black-necked grebe. 
While you can’t help but take part in some bird watching here, there are also walking and biking tracks to help explore this conservation area. 
Tip: While the water may look pretty, it’s best not to pack the Speedos for this trip as swimming is not recommended due to the levels of algae in the water and heavy salinity. An unexpected pink lake in Spain. Source: Supplied 
Seven Coloured Earth of Chamarel, Mauritius 
Covering an area of 7500 square metres this unique phenomenon is one of the main attractions on Mauritius with the sand dunes showing off a brilliant display of seven different colours — red, brown, green, yellow, blue, violet and purple. 
Formed when volcanic rock cooled at different temperatures, it is the only place in the world that has earth of seven colours. 
Take a handful of sand and mix it together. You’ll notice that the different colours separate from each other to form a layered spectrum. 
Tip: Sunrise is the best time to see the Coloured Earths. Looking more like a painting than real life. The Seven Coloured Earth. Source: Supplied 
Huacachina Oasis, Ica, Peru 
This tropical settlement of Huacachina, in Peru, is nestled in the middle of one of the most barren places on earth. 
Built around a small natural lake and surrounded by enormous sand dunes that stretch several hundred metres high, Huacachina has the look and feel of a remote Saharan outpost, but in reality it is only an hour’s drive away from the Pacific coast. 
Home to around 96 residents as well as some hotels and shops it is one of the few remaining natural oases in North and South America. 
Tip: Watch the sunset over the dunes and have a go at sandboarding. A reprieve from the desert heat. Source: Supplied 
Fairy Pools, Glen Brittle, Isle of Skye, Scotland, UK 
At the foot of the Black Cuillins near Glenbrittle are the Fairy Pools. These beautiful, crystal clear blue pools are part of the River Brittle and are open to swimmers brave enough to jump into its freezing waters. 
The walk to the first main pool is 1.2km and will take the average person around 20 minutes to get there. From there take some time to work your way up the river from the first waterfall exploring the different pools. 
Tip: Take care after heavy rainfall when river crossings can become dangerous. Follow the trail of the river and waterfalls and see the series of blue pools. Source: Supplied 
Abraham Lake, Alberta, Canada 
These frozen bubbles under Alberta’s Lake Abraham might look like winter jewels, but you wouldn’t want to be too close to one if it popped: the bubbles are actually frozen pockets of methane, a highly flammable gas. 
The methane bubbles form when dead organic matter such as leaves and animals fall into the water. Bacteria in the water feeds on the matter and poops out methane, which then turns into white floating blobs when it comes into contact with frozen water. 
Tip : You’ll get the best photos at sunrise or sunset but be sure to check the ice thickness first before venturing out on the frozen lake. It looks like something from outer space. Source: Supplied 
Havasu Falls, Arizona, USA 
Most people know about the Grand Canyon in Arizona, but there’s another lesser-known sight — the Havasu Falls. 
Located in a remote canyon of Arizona, the Havasu Falls showcase vibrant blue waters and red rocks and is popular with hikers. 
Tip: Don’t want to hike into the canyon? You can also ride a horse or organise a helicopter to drop you in. 
Danakil Depression, Dallol, Ethiopia 
The Danakil Depression, is a strange lunar landscape studded with active volcanoes, malodorous sulphur-caked hot springs, solidified black lava flows and vast salt-encrusted basins. 
It is renowned as one of the hottest places on Earth with an average temperature of 34-35 degrees Celsius. 
It may be one of the most inhospitable regions in the world, but it’s also one of the most spectacular. 
Tip: Travellers should be self-sufficient in food and water (bank on a minimum of five litres of drinking water each per day, and carry enough excess in jerry cans to last a few days extra) and will need to take camping and cooking gear, since no accommodation or firewood are available. The desert nights can be refreshingly chilly, so bring a light jumper or a sweatshirt. It’s like taking a trip to another planet. Source: Supplied 
Spotted Lake, Osoyoos, British Columbia, Canada 
Ever since ancient times, the Indians of the Okanagan Valley have considered the Spotted Lake a holy place that cured their every illness. 
Whether they were suffering from sprains, infections, skin diseases or body aches, they would get better by immersing their bodies in the lakes waters. Even during times of war, tribes would ask for truce, so warriors could come to Osoyoos Lake and heal their wounds. 
Osoyoos is one of the most mineral-rich bodies of water on Earth, featuring mostly sulfates of magnesium, calcium and sodium. During the summer, as the lake’s water evaporates, it leaves behind the minerals, which take the shape of pools. Each natural pool has a different colour, depending on the type and concentration of the minerals. 
Tip: You cannot walk between the pools anymore. A fence has been erected and viewing must take place behind it. A UFO dotted landscape. Source: Supplied 
Champagne Pool, Rotorua, New Zealand 
This geothermal pool is a hot spring that gets its boozy name from the bubbly nature of its waters. 
The hot spring formed 900 years ago by a hydrothermal eruption, resulting in a crater 65 metres in diameter and 62 metres deep. The coloured waters percolate up from underground full of carbon dioxide which forms bubbles near the surface where the water temperature is a steaming 74 degrees Celsius. 
Tip: Being an active volcanic area with undulating terrain, sturdy footwear is recommended, it is not a good idea to wear jandals, sandals or flip-flops. The waters are constantly simmering away. Source: Supplied
